awd_titl_txt: The Tangled Signaling Pathway of a Bacterial Phytochrome
awd_abstract_narration:
Phytochromes are light-responsive sensory molecules, but exactly how  light is perceived by bacteria and how that information is used to bring about adaptation to changes in light levels is not well understood.  This project will explore how protein folding influences the  signaling pathways of a soluble phytochrome. Additionally, this project will investigate how other proteins (called chaperones) facilitate the protein folding required for proper phytochrome activity. These experiments promise to provide generally applicable insights into phytochromes, and in addition phytochromes will be modified to create new microscopic imaging tools which will permit biologists to peer into living organisms to learn more about basic biological processes.  The project includes outreach activities that facilitate interaction between scientists and artists to enhance science communication and learning.

 The objective of this project is to understand how the unusual knotted topology of bacterial phytochrome determines the signaling properties and folding pathway of this light-regulated histidine kinase. Phytochrome is one of few deeply knotted proteins known, and the route to its figure-of-eight final topology is completely unknown. To determine whether the knotted protein structure of phytochrome and the catenated dimeric interface of its cognate response regulator contribute to intra- and intermolecular signaling, the project will utilize kinase, phosphotransferase, and phosphatase assays on native and untangled (engineered) bacterial phytochromes and their cognate response regulators. To determine how the folding pathway of knotted phytochrome is dependent on characteristics of the proline-rich lasso loop the project will investigate the effects of sequence and length variation in this loop on folding of phytochromes in the presence and absence of a prolyl-isomerase containing chaperone. To create small genetically encoded fluorophores with desirable near infrared excitation maxima, the project will reverse engineer phytochrome by removing domains required only for signal transduction while maintaining elements required for stable folding and chromophore interaction.

por.por_cntn:
Light from the sun serves as the ultimate source of energy for our planet. Living organisms must be able to sense and respond appropriately to light in order to take advantage of it, to avoid its harmful consequences, and to adjust their behaviors according to the intensity and spectrum of light they are currently receiving. An important class of proteins carry out this work, absorbing light of particular colors and carrying out enzymatic roles to harvest energy or signaling functions to change cellular behavior. The work supported by this NSF grant has taught us about two photoactive proteins.

Rhodopsins are well known photoactive proteins in archaea and in eukaryotes, but were only relatively recently identified in marine bacteria.  We have demonstrated that a novel rhodopsin encoded in the genome of the tiny fresh water bacteria acI is produced in lakes, thus suggesting it is indeed useful to acI. We also showed that the acI genome includes all of the enzymes required to synthesize the small molecule cofactor needed by rhodopsin, retinal. In the lab, we demonstrated that this protein, when bound to its retinal partner, is able to use light to drive the movement of protons across membranes.  This work is important because it expands our comprehension of the environments in which this ancient light harvesting machinery may play a role in sustaining life. It has implications for equations that describe the balance of energy, nutrients and growth in fresh water on earth.

Phytochromes are photosensory proteins that use a tetrapyrrole chromophore to sense light in the red and far-red parts of the spectrum and to respond by adjusting the activities of cells and multicellular organisms. The unique structure of phytochrome is that the protein backbone forms a figure-of-eight knot. Our work has demonstrated that the knot is a critical part of the intramolecular signaling pathway in phytochrome. Molecular dynamics simulations suggest a Phytochrome without the knot is a much more dynamic structure. Molecular biology was used to create a knotless phytochrome, and we determined that its activity was no longer regulated by red light. There are few other knotted proteins known, certainly none for which this function has been assigned, making this work unique.

Upon absorption of a light photon, the chromophore within a photoreceptor is fleetingly at a higher energy than in its dark state. If the normal photocycle can be prevented, the energy may be given up as a second lower energy photon ? e.g. fluorescence -- rather than being channeled into molecular motion. We designed a new variant of phytochrome which is brightly fluorescent. We call it WiPhy2 for Wisconsin Infrared Phytochrome, Version 2. This molecule holds great promise for use as an in vivo, genetically encoded dye that will allow visualization of molecules and cells within live animals.

The intriguing structure of Phytochrome led to the initiation of a science art collaborative called Knots in Nature. A small interdisciplinary group including textile artists, a wood artist, a composer, a print maker, museum exhibits curators, and scientists worked together to design an eventual small interactive public exhibit that would challenge viewers to consider knots both real and conceptual. One of the members of this group was an artist-in-residence embedded within the NSF-funded laboratory. His work was influenced by the crystallography and structural biology going on around him, and appeared in several exhibits.
